intro: Gratiola pilosa var. epilis, commonly known as the hairy yellow crowfoot, is a flowering plant native to parts of Europe and Asia. It is characterized by its basal rosette of hairy, lance-shaped leaves and produces clusters of small, bright yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, calcareous soils and is often found in meadows and along stream banks. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is known for its aromatic foliage. The species is generally hardy and can thrive in a variety of temperate climates.
